title-group.article-title: Real and Artificial Differential Item Functioning

fn.p: DAVID ANDRICH is the Chapple Professor of Education at The University of Western Australia, 35 Stirling Highway, Crawley, Western Australia, 6009, AUSTRALIA; e-mail: david.andrich@uwa.edu.au. His interests include the Rasch class of measurement models and the implications that these models have for the design and construction of measuring instruments in the social sciences.

CURT HAGQUIST is Professor of Public Health and Director for the Centre for Research on Child and Adolescent Mental Health at Karlstad University, SE-651 88 Karlstad, Sweden, e-mail: curt.hagquist@kau.se. His interests include applications of the Rasch model for development and evaluation of instruments measuring child and adolescent mental health.

abstract.p: The literature in modern test theory on procedures for identifying items with differential item functioning (DIF) among two groups of persons includes the Mantel–Haenszel (MH) procedure. Generally, it is not recognized explicitly that if there is real DIF in some items which favor one group, then as an artifact of this procedure, artificial DIF that favors the other group is induced in the other items. Using the Rasch model for dichotomous responses as a theoretical basis, this article proves that the source of artificial DIF in the MH procedure is that estimates of the person locations are substituted for their unknown values. The article then demonstrates that the formalization of artificial DIF implies mathematically (a) a particular sequential, iterative procedure for detecting items with real DIF and for identifying a set of items that may have no DIF and (b) a resolution of the items with real DIF for quantifying the DIF on the same metric as the items showing no DIF and provides expected value curves and tests of fit for the item for each of the groups. Finally, because the source of artificial DIF in the MH procedure is the substitution of a parameter with its estimate, it is suggested that all procedures that use the substitution of an estimate for a parameter are likely to induce artificial DIF.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Valid quantitative comparisons between groups from questionnaire or assessment data require items to work invariantly between these groups. In the terminology of modern test theory, in which the response of a person to an item is characterized by a probabilistic model, items should show no differential item functioning (DIF) between these groups. No DIF on an item implies that, for the same value on the variable, the expected value of a response to the item from persons from different identifiable groups is the same. In the case of dichotomously scored items, the expected value reduces to the probability of a positive response. The dominant discussion in the literature on DIF is that of two identifiable groups, and we focus on such a case in this article. In addition, some methods focus on a minority group relative to a majority group where the latter might be referred to as the focal group, while others simply assess whether or not items work invariantly between groups of equal status, say between genders. In the example of this article, we take two groups that are taken to be of equal status. We also simplify the discussion in this article by considering only dichotomous responses. However, the principles generalize to items with polytomous responses.

Many procedures have been proposed for studying DIF for both dichotomously and polytomous scored items (e.g. Budgel, Raju, & Quartetti, 1995; Cho & Cohen, 2010; Ironson, 1983; Penfield & Lam, 2000; Potenza & Dorens, 1995; Rousssos, Schnipke, & Pashley, 1999; Wang, 2000; Zwick, Donoghue, & Grima, 1993). Many procedures for identifying a subset of items that has no DIF have also been described. This article contributes to understanding the justification and implications of one of these procedures.

A general problem, mostly not taken into account explicitly and formally in typical procedures for assessing DIF, is that real DIF in some items favoring one group can induce the appearance of DIF in others favoring the other group where this latter DIF is an artifact of the procedure for identifying DIF. Not only has it not been taken account of formally, but there seems no specific terminology that reflects DIF as an artifact of the procedure that is used to assess it. We therefore introduce the terminology of artificial DIF for this kind of DIF, and of real DIF for that DIF which is inherent to an item and not an artifact of any procedure used to detect it. Artificial DIF can lead to misidentifying items as having real DIF and to giving the mistaken impression that the effect of DIF among items where some items favor one group and others favor the other group cancel in comparing the means of two groups.

One terminology for a related concept is that of false negative or a false positive identification of DIF for an item. In probabilistic models of modern test theory chance inevitably plays a role, and therefore false negatives and positives are also inherently possible by chance. The rate of these will clearly be a function of the magnitude of the DIF, the number favoring one or other group, the sample size, and the total number of items, and other violations of the model chosen to identify DIF. We wish to distinguish chance effects from the case where the presence of DIF in one or more items favoring one group induces or causes the appearance of DIF in other items favoring the other group. The terminology of false negatives and positives does not immediately convey the idea that DIF in one or more items, together with the procedure for identifying DIF, causes the appearance of DIF in other items that have no real DIF. A second terminology that has appeared in the literature which captures the same idea is that of spurious DIF. This term has arisen out of the observation that DIF which should not appear seems to appear in some methods for detecting DIF, an observation which, however, is not explained as to how it is an artifact of the procedure that was used. Once again, we consider that the term artificial captures the nature of this DIF as it can be explained, as it is in this article, as an artifact of the procedure.

Although noticed in the literature (e.g., Wang, Bradlow, Wainer, & Muller, 2008; Wang & Su, 2004), and although not explained formally, iterative procedures that have been proposed for identifying subsets of items with no DIF implicitly and incidentally deal with artificial DIF (e.g., Candell & Drasgow, 1988). In contrast, a more recent example in which a noniterative procedure for the simultaneous detection of DIF is proposed, no mention is made of the concept of artificial DIF (Soares, Goncalves, & Gamerman, 2009). Finally, we note that a relatively recent summary of the state of the art of DIF shows an awareness but no explanation of artificial DIF: “Sometimes, for reasons unknown, calculations of a DIF detection strategy may suggest DIF, where none truly exists” (Osterlind & Everson, 2009, p. 21).

In summary, there seems to be no literature that proves how some procedures for identifying DIF induce artificial DIF. As a consequence, the procedures for identifying subsets of the items with no DIF are described as a result of empirical and simulated observations, but without a theoretical rationale. The advantage of having a theoretical rationale for artificial DIF is that it can imply an approach to identifying sets of items with no real DIF. Thus one of the results of the proof of artificial DIF shown in this article is that it implies, first, a rationale for identifying a set of items with no DIF, and second, a rationale based on the definition of DIF for quantifying the amount of DIF in terms of the metric of the items that have no DIF.

We may understand the importance of a theoretical explanation of artificial DIF by observing that if artificial DIF did not exist, then identifying subsets of items with no DIF would be simple. Specifically, all items that show DIF could be dealt with, for example, eliminated, sequentially, simultaneously, or in any other combination of ways, and the same subset of items with no DIF would be identified. That it is not this simple is demonstrated by the vast literature on identifying subsets of items with no DIF. While the purpose of this article is to provide a formal explanation of artificial DIF and a rationale that follows for detecting, accounting for, and quantifying DIF, the purpose of the article is not to survey this vast literature, other than to note that it does not prove the existence of artificial DIF in some procedures for detecting DIF.

The article explains how artificial DIF is induced and how it can be handled to distinguish it from real DIF in one of the earliest and most popular heuristic methods of identifying DIF, the Mantel and Haenszel (MH) (1959) procedure, elaborated in some detail by Holland and Thayer (1988). In this procedure, persons are classified by their total scores on the set of items. Like these authors, the article integrates the approach with the Rasch (1960/1980, 1961) model (RM) of modern test theory in which classifying persons by their total scores arises from the model and is not essentially heuristic. The relationship between tests for DIF using the RM and the MH procedures has also been noted in the literature by other authors (Schultz, Perlman, Rice, & Wright, 1996; Verguts & De Boeck, 2001).

As with the general awareness of the concept of artificial DIF as an empirical observation, it has been specifically observed with the MH procedure: “… the M-H-1 tends to declare mistakenly those DIF-free items as DIF items favoring the focal group and to declare mistakenly those DIF items as DIF-free items under these conditions. This tendency makes the total DIF yielded via M-H-1 more or less balanced between groups, when in fact all or most of the DIF items are simulated to favor the reference group” (Wang & Su, 2004, p. 141). Tennant and Pallant (2007) make a similar observation.

We stress that because of the central role of the total score in both the Rasch model and the MH procedure, this relationship between them is not merely a juxtaposition of two procedures, but an extension of the latter with the Rasch model. We might also add that the case for the Rasch model is that of invariance of comparisons among items, irrespective of subsets of persons along the variable, vice versa for the comparisons of persons. This requirement of invariance of items with respect to subsets of persons along the variable extends readily to the invariance across different subsets of persons based on demographic characteristics, for example, males and females. Thus the misfit to the Rasch model because of lack invariance among groups and the MH procedure are reflections of each other. On the other hand, forming class intervals based on the total scores and then using a non-Rasch IRT model to study DIF, as is done with some procedures that we have no space to consider, does seem ad hoc.

sec.title: 1.1. The Source of Artificial DIF in Standard Identification Procedures
sec.p: In anticipation of the formal developments of the article, the source of artificial DIF is now summarized. As indicated above, the definition of no DIF is that for the same value on the trait, persons from different identifiable groups will have the same probability of a positive response. However, in detecting DIF in data, the value on the variable of any person is not known. Instead, in general it is estimated simultaneously with the effort to diagnose DIF. Accordingly, the unknown value on the variable for persons is substituted by their estimates. In the case where all items are analyzed simultaneously in the detection of DIF, this substitution is the source of artificial DIF. In the case of the RM, this is explicit—classifying persons by their total scores is equivalent to grouping persons who have the same location estimate. However, as is shown, the substitution of the estimate for the unknown value is not obviated in the MH procedure when the Rasch model is not invoked explicitly. The insight and understanding of the presence of artificial DIF in the MH procedure, however, is provided by the RM. In addition, as will be shown, invoking the RM permits an extension of the MH procedure in identifying items with real DIF. The possibility of this extension is again emphasized by the inherent, rather than ad hoc, relationship between the MH procedure for detecting DIF and misfit to the Rasch model.

To make concrete how artificial DIF is induced in the presence of real DIF, responses to three items will be used to illustrate the general derivations. Although three items is small for real data analyses, there is an important, common application where DIF in a small number of items can have a powerful measurement effect. This application concerns the linking of tests, including in education where tests are linked either across different years of educational study or over time, and where relatively few items, generally less than 10, from 30 or so items, form a link. Then if for some structural reason two items show DIF favoring the same group, it is one third of the link items, and depending on the size of the DIF, it can induce harmful DIF in equating, and can produce artificial DIF which may appear to help cancel out the real DIF. Such an example with 30 items, 6 of which are in common and simulated to parallel a real example of linking achievement between two year levels of schooling, is provided. It shows clearly that the artificial DIF in two such items manifests itself as artificial DIF in some other items. The procedure for quantifying and accounting for this DIF described in the example with three items is then applied in this example of a linking design.

The rest of the article is structured as follows. Section 2 summarizes the property of sufficiency in the Rasch model. Section 3 uses the Rasch model to establish artificial DIF. Section 4 demonstrates artificial DIF appearing in the MH procedure with the case of three items, one of which has real DIF. Section 5 introduces the logic of resolving an item for the purpose of confirming, quantifying, and removing the effect of DIF. Section 6 demonstrates the logic of resolving items hypothesized to have DIF sequentially beginning with the item with evidence of the greatest DIF. Section 7 shows the simulation of a linked example, and Section 8 is a summary and discussion which considers implications of the procedure and the presence of artificial DIF in other methods of detecting DIF.

sec.title: 3. The Theoretical Foundation for Artificial DIF—Illustrations Based on the Rasch Model
sec.p: Table 1 shows the location values of three items, which we use to illustrate the derivations, with the conditional probabilities of Equation 5. We now explain the rationale and consequence for grouping persons by total score in the RM. Our aim is to identify those items in which, given the same location of persons on the latent variable, there might be a difference in the expected value of a response. However, suppose, as is generally the case, that we do not have a known value of the latent variable. Then as a proxy, persons must be grouped by some rationale. As stressed above, in the case of the RM, and used in the MH procedure, the rationale for grouping persons by their total score is that persons with the same total score have the same estimate. This of course does not mean that persons with the same total score really have the same value on the variable, just that they have the same estimate, and grouping the persons who have the same estimate is the best that can be done in the circumstances. This formalization of artificial DIF and how it is distributed achieves the first major purpose of the article. It is suggested that this mathematical formalization and explication of the way real and artificial DIF interact, not presented elsewhere in the literature, advances the understanding of the interplay of real and artificial DIF and therefore by implication how it can be identified and dealt with. The rest of the article shows some of these implications.

For example, because the magnitude of real DIF affects the degree of artificial DIF, and because the artificial DIF is distributed across all other items, it makes artificial DIF also a function of the number of items. It is clear that with only one item having some DIF in the presence of 20 or 30 items, the artificial DIF will be negligible. It is equally clear that with a small number of items, perhaps in a linking study with 6 common items, and with say 2 items showing DIF favoring the same group by a noticeable amount, that artificial DIF in 1 or more other items might appear significant. It should also be evident that some items might exhibit a combination of real and artificial DIF. Lest the point of artificial DIF be lost, we will not carry out various simulation studies to give guidelines on the relative impacts of these effects. This is left for other occasions. However, as indicated in Section 1, we provide one simulated example illustratively where two tests are equated with a small number of items that form a link between the tests.

sec.title: 5. Resolving Items Sequentially to Estimate the Magnitude of Real DIF
sec.p: Holland and Thayer (1988) provide a comprehensive analysis of the estimation of the magnitude of DIF in any item assuming the Rasch model and discuss the advantages and disadvantages of including and excluding the item for which the significance of DIF is assessed in the formation of total scores. We now consider a procedure for simultaneously confirming whether DIF is real or artificial and for estimating the magnitude and significance of real DIF in the metric defined by the remaining items. This procedure incorporates the item hypothesized to have DIF in forming groups by their total scores. However, it does not incorporate it by simply including it in the total score in the usual way.

First we note that we have established above that a reasonable hypothesis is that the item with the largest DIF (in this case calculated by the MH procedure) is the one with the real DIF. It also follows immediately that in confirming real DIF in Item 1, and therefore complementary-wise establishing a set of items with no DIF, that Item 1 needs to be dealt with first. Thus it follows that the handling of the items with DIF (recall Items 1 and 3 show DIF according to
M H
c h i - s q u a r e
) should be carried out sequentially. A logic for doing so, although described in the literature as one of a number of procedures for obtaining a set of items showing no DIF, seems not to have been provided elsewhere. It also suggests that this sequential approach, having an algebraic logic behind it, and all other factors equal, is the most reasonable to proceed with first in any real situation.

Second, to account and quantify the hypothesized real DIF in Item 1, we resolve this item into two new items, one item has responses for only girls and the other responses for only boys. We call these the resolved girl and resolved boy items. (When no reference is made to gender, then the term resolved item refers to the original item.) In the above example with three items, Item 1 is resolved so that there are then four items, but the two resolved items have respectively only either girls or boys, and not both, responding to them. Thus the new items have structurally missing responses on the two resolved girl and boy items. In addition, the data matrix has now one extra item, in this case four.

Such a data matrix with missing data can be analyzed readily according to the Rasch model using modern software with the person parameter eliminated by conditioning on the total scores. It will be shown analytically that the following results follow. First, if the item that is resolved is the only one that has real DIF, then the remaining items will show no artificial DIF. Second, the difference in the location estimates of the two resolved girl and boy items is an estimate of the magnitude of DIF in the metric defined by the remaining items. Third, an item characteristic curve (ICC) showing the expected value curve for boys and girls for the items, which reflects the very definition of DIF, can be shown. Fourth, and finally, with the availability of standard errors of these estimates, a significance test can be conducted for the magnitude of DIF. We derive the equations and illustrate the procedure below using again the example with three items above.

sec.title: 6.2. The MH Procedure Following the Resolution of Item 1
sec.p: We now calculate conditional probabilities, not from one set of item parameter estimates for all items, but with the separate estimates for the resolved items of Item 1 for boys and girls. In this case, the original item 1 is removed, with only the resolved girl and boy items present. This accounts for DIF. It accounts for DIF in Item 1 because from estimated probabilities in which Item 1 has different estimates for girls and boys, it expects different proportions of boys and girls with the same total score to have Item 1 correct. However, because the estimates appear in the conditional probabilities of responses to Items 2 and 3, it predicts and accounts for the artificial DIF in Items 2 and 3. sec.title: 7. A Simulation Based on a Real Example
sec.p: It was indicated in Section 1 that a case where a small number of items may be involved and where DIF can produce misleading comparisons was in linking designs where different groups are assessed with different items, but where there are some common items, known as link items. Often there are less than 10 items in the link. We simulate an example where we take as a basis for the simulation a real study reported by Looveer and Mulligan (2009). In the study they reported, where they analyzed the data with the dichotomous RM, vertical links were made for assessments in mathematics across seven years of elementary school, Kindergarten to Year 6. Estimates of the performances of all students were placed on the same scale, and the means of all seven year levels reported. However, in the first analysis of their data, which involved analyzing the whole data matrix with structurally missing responses, they found that the range of item difficulties for all year levels seemed to be the same, and further, that the means of proficiencies of all year levels seemed to be the same. They report the details of the analysis in which DIF was identified statistically and then studied qualitatively to understand substantively the reasons the items showed DIF. When DIF in the items was controlled, then the range of item difficulties and the mean proficiencies for each year level appeared as expected—the means of the item difficulties and student proficiencies increased with successive year levels.

We simulate a data set according to the RM based on the statistics reported in the Looveer and Mulligan study, but we only consider two year levels, those having a structure and values in parallel with Years 3 and 4. Tables 10 and 11
show the design of the simulated example, with and without the DIF items. The example without DIF provides a frame of reference for the estimates in the case with DIF. The mean and standard deviations of the persons was the same in both simulations, having a logit mean difference of .7 (in the real study after accounting for DIF the difference was .680). The location of the persons relative to the location of the items was such that the person at the mean of each person distribution had a probability of .75 of answering the item with average difficulty. This again is in parallel to the real example where it is considered important that the students do not find the items so difficult that the validity of their engagement is questionable. The distributions simulated were normal with the standard deviation of the Year 4 group slightly greater than that of the Year 3 group, again as in the real example.

caption.p: Design of the Simulation Link Example With No DIF
Design of the Simulation Link Example With Two Items Having Real DIF

sec.p: The total number of items each student sat is 23 (in the real study they were 20 and 25 in Years 3 and 4, respectively). There were 6 link items leaving 17 unique items for each year level. In the simulation with DIF, 2 items favored the Year 3 group by 2 logits. This is a substantial size but it is also the size of the one specific example provided in the Looveer and Mulligan study.

A large DIF favoring the younger group can appear because of curriculum changes whereby the Year 4 group has not had exposure to an item in Year 3, or if the material was not consolidated in Year 4, and the Year 4 students had forgotten the details enough to do poorly on the item, and so on. These are only hypotheses regarding such possibilities, and this example is meant to illustrate the prediction and control of artificial DIF in a realistic situation.

We first report the results of the simulation example on the means and standard deviations of the persons, and then we report a summary of evidence of real and artificial DIF in the items. The simulated data were analyzed interactively according to the RM with the software RUMM2030 (Andrich, Sheridan, & Luo, 2010).

sec.title: 7.1. The Means and Standard Deviations of the Person Estimates
sec.p: Table 12 shows the means and standard deviations recovered for the Year 3 and Year 4 groups under three conditions: (a) no DIF, (b) in the presence of DIF, and (c) when the two DIF items were resolved to each provide unique, resolved items for the two groups. The following points are evident from Table 12. First, the magnitude of the estimates is of the correct order in both the no DIF case and when the items with DIF are resolved in the manner described in Section 5. Second, the magnitude of the estimates of the means for the two year groups in the case of DIF is grossly out of order—the estimates are not statistically different. This is exactly the result obtained by Looveer and Mulligan, with estimates across year levels equivalent before they dealt with items which showed DIF. The results in the table establish that resolving the items with DIF accounts for the DIF in estimating the person locations.

sec.title: 7.2. Analysis of DIF items
sec.p: Rather than reporting tables, we use ICCs to demonstrate graphically the evidence and effects of real and artificial DIF in the analysis. This permits visualization of the effects relative to the definition of no DIF, namely, that for the same value on the latent variable, the expected values of persons from two groups are the same. Recall that six items, 18 to 23 are link items, and that Items 20 and 21 had two logits DIF favoring Year 3.

The first analysis of the responses where two items had DIF favoring the Year 3 year level was of the whole data matrix with structurally missing responses on items where the two year levels responded to different items. The only common items were the six link items. We display the ICCs and the means of responses of the two year groups in each of the 10 class intervals based on adjacent total scores. The observed means are the counterpart of expected values, given estimates on the latent variable. Class intervals were formed to have as equal numbers as possible. The observed means were plotted against the mean of the estimates on the latent variable of members of each class interval. These class interval means are also shown in the figures. In the case of resolved items, these class interval means are generally slightly different for the year groups.

We first display, in Figure 2 , the ICCs of two items, Items 9 and 32. These items were chosen because they had similar difficulty estimates to Items 20 and 21, and because they respectively had responses for Years 3 and 4 only. Their display provides a frame of reference for considering the graphs of Items 20 and 21 with DIF. It is evident that the means in the class intervals for the year groups are relatively close to their respective ICCs with no major systematic deviations.

caption.p: ICCs and observed means in 10 class intervals for Items 9 and 32.

sec.p: Figure 3 shows the estimated ICCs for Items 20 and 21, together with the means of the class intervals of the groups. It is evident that, as expected from the specifications in the simulation, the observed means of the persons in class intervals are greater for Year 3 than Year 4—there is substantial DIF favoring Year 3. Statistically, Item 20 had a slightly greater DIF than Item 21 and had the greatest DIF overall.

caption.p: ICCs and observed means in 10 class intervals for Items 20 and 21.

sec.p: At the same time, all other link items showed significant DIF favoring Year 4. Figure 4 shows the ICC curves and means in 10 class intervals for Items 19 and 23 which respectively showed the least and greatest DIF favoring Year 4. It is evident that the DIF in these items favoring Year 4 is not as great as that of Items 20 and 21, which favored Year 3. As proved in Equation 8, this is as expected—the magnitude of real DIF in Items 20 and 21 favoring one direction, is distributed exactly across all the other items in the opposite direction ensuring that the artificial DIF is smaller per item than the real DIF.

caption.p: ICCs and observed means in 10 class intervals for Items 19 and 23.

sec.p: This also confirms the logic of the sequential resolution of the items showing DIF, beginning with the one showing greatest DIF and then continuing with the next one showing the greatest DIF, and so on. We resolved Items 20 and 21 sequentially. Figure 5 shows the resolved ICCs for Items 20 and 21 when they are both resolved, together with the observed means in 10 class intervals. They show clearly that, for the same value on the latent variable, the expected values for the two year levels on the two items are different and that the items are more difficult for Year 4 than for Year 3.

caption.p: ICCs and observed means in 10 class intervals for resolved Items 20 and 21.

sec.p: For completeness, Figure 6 show similar resolved ICCs for Items 19 and 23, after items 20 and 21 were resolved. It is evident that these items, as did all other link items, no longer show DIF. Thus the resolution of the items with real DIF removed the appearance of DIF in the other items, which confirmed that the DIF in these other items was artificial—it was induced by Items 20 and 21 which had real DIF favoring Year 3. Finally, we note that when we resolved one of the items with only artificial DIF first, it did not remove the evidence of DIF in Items 20 and 21 which had real DIF. Thus the logic of resolving the items sequentially, in each case resolving the item with the greatest DIF, has held in the simulated example.

caption.p: ICCs and observed means in 10 class intervals for resolved Items 19 and 23 after Items 20 and 21 with real DIF are resolved.

sec.p: At one level, eliminating items that show real DIF will have the same effect on the means and standard deviations of the groups to be compared as resolving these items. However, there are two advantages in pursuing the resolution of items sequentially rather than eliminating items that show DIF. The first is that in proceeding sequentially, items that might be showing artificial DIF are not eliminated. And in the case of a linking design, where there might be relatively few link items, it is important not to eliminate items that need not be eliminated. Second, if, on resolution of the items, the fit is consistent with the model, then because the same number of items is retained for each person, no precision is lost as it is when items are eliminated.

sec.title: 8. Summary and Discussion
sec.p: This article revisits one of the earliest procedures for assessing DIF, the MH procedure, and, with the aid of the Rasch model, makes explicit that as an artifact of the procedure, real DIF that favors one group in an item will induce artificial DIF of the same magnitude favoring the other group distributed among the other items. Two implications were shown to follow. First, the presence of artificial DIF in some items is more likely to manifest itself as artificial DIF in other items if the number of items is not large. However, if artificial DIF does appear in the presence of a large number of items, then it implies that the real DIF in some items is relatively large. Second, it implies that an item which has the greatest apparent magnitude of DIF when the MH procedure is applied to all items can be hypothesized to be the one with real DIF. Of course, in practical situations, an item with the largest apparent DIF in a first analysis could be one that has some real DIF and some artificial DIF in the same direction, and when the artificial DIF is accounted for, it might not be the item with the largest real DIF.

An approach for distinguishing between real and artificial DIF, which follows from the analysis and understanding of real and artificial DIF, is also described in the article. This approach involves beginning with the full complement of items and then resolving the item that shows the greatest DIF into two items, where one item has only one group responding to it, and the other item the other group. These are referred to as resolved items for the respective groups. If the DIF is real, then it was shown that the procedure eliminates artificial DIF in the other items and that these other items can then be assessed for further real DIF.

An alternate to checking whether the item is generating artificial DIF is to simply eliminate the item. However, there are advantages in resolving the item identified as having the greatest DIF. First, if the Rasch model is used as a basis for the MH procedure, then a test of fit of the item to the model for each group can be assessed. If there is misfit, it suggests further interactions not accounted for by the resolution of the item. Second, as a by-product of the procedure, the magnitude of the DIF in the metric of the items with no DIF can be estimated. Third, the number of data points for each person remains the same and therefore the precision of the estimates is retained. However, even if for some reason one chose to eliminate items showing DIF, rather than to resolve them, then it follows that they should not be eliminated simultaneously but sequentially, starting with the item with the largest apparent DIF.

One of the consequences of the appearance of artificial DIF is that it can give the impression that DIF of items favoring one group balances out with DIF favoring the other group implying that, in the person locations, the effect of DIF will somehow be compensated. However, because the DIF in some items is an artifact of the procedure for assessing DIF, the artificial DIF cannot affect the estimates of the persons; only the real DIF will affect the estimates of the person locations.

This observation leads to another advantage of the procedure of resolving items—it accounts for the DIF in the estimation of the person locations of the two groups. It does this because the item for the groups has different estimates—those who find it easier will have a lower difficulty estimate for the item than those who find it more difficult. Then in the presence of structurally missing data, persons with the same total score in the two groups will not have the same location estimate: For the same total score, those in the group which find the item easier will have a lower ability estimate than those who find it more difficult. Thus the procedure can be used to assess, and compensate for, the impact of DIF on the person measures using all items. The resolution of items and the application of the MH procedure rest on using the RM and could not be carried out without exploiting the sufficiency of the total score in the RM. Of course, to use estimates based on the resolution of DIF, it is necessary to be assured from a qualitative analysis of the items and the context that the DIF arises from some factor or factors irrelevant to the variable being assessed and that the DIF generates real bias in the estimates. However, this caveat also holds for eliminating an item that shows DIF—this too changes the relative standing of groups and it is necessary to be assured that this change is justified from evidence beyond the statistical evidence.

The reason that the MH procedure, as analyzed through the Rasch model, generates artificial DIF can be traced to the substitution of the estimates of the person locations for unknown values. In the Rasch model, the person total score is a sufficient statistic for the person parameter estimate, and therefore grouping persons by total scores is equivalent to grouping persons according to their estimates. Thus, rather than assessing if, given the same value on the trait the probability of a positive response is the same for two groups, the procedure assesses whether given the same estimate on the trait the probability of a positive response is the same. Grouping persons by the estimate provides a constraint on the sum of the estimated probabilities (and proportions) of a positive response across all items, given the same total score. Thus the sum of the probabilities, or proportions, of positive responses across items of persons with a total score of r must be r. Therefore, if because of real DIF in one item favoring one group the probability (or proportion) is greater in that group, artificial DIF which favors the other group must be induced in the other items.

In the Rasch model, and in the MH procedure applied with or without the Rasch model, this effect can be made explicit, as has been done in this article. However, while less explicit, we suggest that the same argument may generalize to any model and procedure in which the item for which DIF is being assessed is used in the estimation of the person locations, and persons and estimates of person locations are substituted for the unknown values. This generalization is suggested because in all estimation methods there is a constraint imposed on the model probabilities in the solution equations. Many procedures involve these two properties, first the inclusion of the studied item and second the substitution of the estimate for the unknown value. Therefore, it may be judicious for these procedures, and the studies which apply them, to be revisited with the possibility of artificial DIF recognized.

Another consequence of the real DIF in one item being distributed as artificial DIF across all other items is that it becomes clear algebraically, rather than only empirically, that the magnitude of artificial DIF is a function of the number of items with real DIF, the direction of the DIF, and the total number of items. The statistical significance of the DIF will also depend on the usual factors of the alignment of the items to the sample of persons and of the sample size. In this case, some modest real DIF favoring one group, combined with artificial DIF resulting from an item which favors another group, may lead to an item having substantial DIF. Therefore, the presence and effects of artificial DIF cannot be dismissed simply because there are many items. As indicated above, if there is artificial DIF in the presence of many items, then it indicates that perhaps a few items have very large real DIF.

Finally, the logic of understanding how artificial DIF is induced was shown to imply the procedure for identifying and accounting for real DIF. Specifically, it implies that all items be considered in the first analysis, and that the item showing the largest magnitude of DIF should be resolved sequentially, one at a time, beginning with the item showing the greatest DIF. It was shown that resolving an item that had real DIF meant that it no longer induced artificial DIF in other items. A corollary is that if an item that has artificial DIF, or predominantly artificial DIF, is resolved first, then it will not remove any real DIF present in other items. In making a final decision for each item whether it has real or artificial DIF, an analysis that begins by resolving an item that is deemed to have artificial DIF may be helpful as a form of triangulation in confirming which items have predominately real and which have predominately artificial DIF. It also follows logically that iterative procedures that begin with a subset of items that shows no DIF may exclude items for which DIF is artificial.

The principles described for distinguishing real and artificial DIF among dichotomous items generalize to polytomous items but is outside the scope of this article where the focus is on drawing attention to the logic of artificial DIF itself. We conclude by suggesting that the above understanding of the nature of artificial DIF is a prerequisite for properly responding to the remarks made by Dorans and Holland (1993) that “Future research should focus on trying to uncover testable, verifiable, robust explanations for why DIF occurs when it does” (p. 66).
